etymologies: late Middle English (in the sense ‘be united physically’; rare before the 18th century): from Latin connectere, from con- ‘together’ + nectere ‘bind’

definitions: bring together or into contact so that a real or notional link is established

examples.text: the electrodes were connected to a recording device
a modem connects computers over a telephone line

definitions: join together so as to provide access and communication

examples.text: all the buildings are connected by underground passages
the highway connects with major routes from all parts of the country

definitions: link to a power or water supply

examples.text: your house is connected to the main cable TV network
I was quickly connected to the police

definitions: (of a train, bus, aircraft, etc.) be timed to arrive at its destination before another train, aircraft, etc., departs so that passengers can transfer from one to the other

examples.text: the bus connects with trains from Union Station

shortDefinitions: arrive just before another train etc.

definitions: associate or relate in some respect

examples.text: employees are rewarded with bonuses connected to their firm's performance
a variety of physical complaints connected with stress

definitions: think of as being linked or related

examples.text: I didn't connect the two incidents at the time

shortDefinitions: think of as being linked or related

definitions: (of a thing) provide or have a link or relationship with (someone or something)

examples.text: there was no evidence to connect Jeff with the theft

definitions: form a relationship or feel an affinity

examples.text: I taught in a reading program and I connected with kids individually

definitions: (of a blow) hit the intended target

examples.text: the blow connected and he felt a burst of pain
